reviewText:
Bejeweled 3 is probably one of the best Match 3 games available on Steam, or if not, then it's definitely the most complex one. It features various game styles, thus satisfying different gamer personalities.

If you like to be under pressure, then there's the Lightning Mode, in which you have a timer that you can be increased by quickly match some special time gems. Diamond mine provides a similar tension: there's a timer too, but in this mode you dig in the stone and sand by matching 3 - 5 gems in order to uncover treasures. However the most stressful game mode is probably Ice Storm - in which you have to fight the climbing columns of ice that quickly threaten to cover the entire board; to prevent this you need to have quick reflexes and a very good perception of the available matches. In order to beat this game mode, I had to switch to mouse and keyboard controls (mouseovering the tile selects it and WASD moves it in the corresponding direction).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446286039

On the contrary, for those that like a more relaxed approach, there's the Zen mode - the classic Match 3 in which you can enable/disable different relaxing background effects and positive affirmations. Another relaxed mode, but more suitable for those that have an analytical mind or love to strategically solve a puzzle, is the Butterfly mode, in which some of the gems are transformed into butterflies that automatically move one tile up whenever another match is made; having one of them reach the top of the board ends the game. This implies that you have to plan ahead your moves and optimize the matches so that they contain as many butterflies as possible.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446286100

I found Poker mode to be the least attractive of all these modes - you are required to build certain poker hands by having consecutive matches of the same colors. It's a game of chance, since your poker hands highly depend on the randomness of the current tiles.

Lastly, there's the Quest mode that contains 40 variations of all these described above: finding a certain number of treasures or freeing a certain number of butterflies, or ticking bombs that need to be matched before the timer wears off etc.

The game adapts itself to the game mode you're playing. For example, in Diamond Mine or Ice Storm mode the game will provide you with suitable gems to create matches or 4 or 5 which result in special gems that help clearing up the board faster. In Poker mode you’re more likely to have gems of the same color grouped together, thus facilitating the process of obtaining good poker hands.

All-in-all, this is a good Match 3 game, if you enjoy the style. But it's quite addictive, so it will probably keep you entertained for hours. Even more so, going for 100% achievements requires a lot of time of grinding.

reviewText:
Long before there was Candy Crush, there was Bejeweled. This is a simple, casual game with a grid that requires you to shift colored jewels and match them into lines of 3 - 5. You can only shift 2 jewels if it will result in a line of 3+ matching colors. Very easy game, but where this game blossoms is all of the mini games / variations of it. Dozens of modes, all centered around making lines. There is classic mode that has you going through levels making lines, lightning rush, which has a very limited time and you need to collect time ups to keep going, diamond mine, where you need to match lines near the bottom rock to destroy the rock and progress further down. Bejeweled poker which every line is like a hand gains you something similar to a card in poker. Butterfly mode has you making lines with jewel butterflies to keep them from reaching the top of the screen where it will be an end of game. There is also a never ending zen mode, which is just like classic only without levels that break the flow of what you have going. Finally, there is an ice breaker mode which forces you to keep up with rising and freezing water. Once a line gets frozen enough its game over.

In a way, I prefer Candy Crush, because they have focus on levels, rather than letting you free to pick modes to play. I just feel overwhelmed with all of the choices and just end up playing 'classic' mode for the most part. On a plus side, unlike Candy Crush, there are no micro transactions. You've bought the whole game and need to unlock the modes.

Bejeweled 3 has a level system that keeps track of all of your points throughout all of your games and a high score amongst your friends. That seems to be my real driving force to play the game, just to beat my friend's high scores and since every time you play, you start with a random grid of jewels, its got something to do with luck as well as skill.

I can recommend the game, but I could recommend it more on the phone. I just feel there are better games I could be playing on my PC than something as simple as this. Tetris sold Gameboys, not  Nintendo Entertainment Systems.

reviewText:
Bejeweled 3 is what they call a 'match 3' game, meaning you need to combine three or more of the same items on the game board, which then disappear, to score points. In this case those items are jewels that come in 7 different colors.

You decide how complex you want this basic principle to become by selecting one of the 8 game modes. Some modes are very casual, like 'classic', 'poker' and 'zen'. Others are more intense because they add a timer of some sort to the game board. There is also a 'quest mode' in which you will play all of the game modes in some form, easy versions at first and more difficult with each level. You don't need to finish all of the games of one level in order to play games from the next level, so if there are one or two game modes you don't like, it's no problem to just skip those each time and progress to the next level anyway.

In each mode, the game will explain clearly what the objective is and what the specific 'twists' for that game mode are.

The background music is quite nice but you can switch it off through the Options menu if you want.

There are a lot of Steam Achievements to be had, which adds even more challenges. Some achievements are built up to by simply playing the game, others are specific goals to be reached in one or more of the game modes.

I recommend giving Bejeweled 3 a try if you're at least a bit into puzzle games, and even more so if you can get it on sale.

Whether you are looking for a mindless relaxing game, a challenging puzzle, or a strategic race against the clock, this game has a mode for you! The music is great, the narrator sounds epic, and the graphics are gorgeous and shiny. I warn you now, you WILL become addicted to this game.

There are four regular modes and four unlockable secret modes.

Classic Mode: The matching game we all know and love. Match three or more in a row for points until there are no more available matches. Match four or more to create powerful special gems.

Zen Mode: Same as classic, but endless as your moves never run out. There are also additional options you can add for relaxation such as aural tones and breath modulation. I like to play this mode on mute while I listen to a podcast or the news.

Ligtning Mode: Race against the clock and get as many points as possible! You can extend your time by matching up the special time gems. Match quickly to get a speed bonus.

Quest Mode: Forty puzzles and eleven mini-games all using the various available modes but with a specific objective. Beat the clock, only use so many moves, etc.

The Secret Modes: Butterflies, Diamond Mine, Ice Storm, and Poker.

I'll let you discover those on your own. Personally my favorite of those is Poker, with Diamond Mine a close second. Now get this game already, and have fun! :)

reviewText: Out of all the nostalgia that old PC games brought me since Windows 98, one that stood out for me was the Bejeweled Deluxe series. In Bejeweled 2, you saw a massive installment in comparison to the first immediately. You could do puzzles and explore beautifully designed planets all while using your head to solve complex puzzles throughout your journey. Also it introduced us to the amazing use of the Hyper Cube and the Flame gem. The art alone still is breathtaking to look at if you played B2 today. As a fellow artist. I can appreciate the amount of skill and determination these developers put in to create these beautiful and stunning planetary landscapes. reviewText:
This is a really fun game with a different mode for ever mood; Classic (match jewels in a line of 3 or more to blow them up), Zen (same as classic but you'll never run out of moves), Lightening (blow up the jewels as fast as possible, you’ll be judges on speed, combos and the difficulty of them) and Quest (restore five items by completing eight minigames tasks per item, e.g. match jewels close to the ground to dig it away an collect five gold before the time is up).

The modes also come a secret game each; Poker, Butterflies, Ice Storm and Diamond Mine. These are locked until you've reached a certain level in the various modes and are new exiting variations of Bejeweled (so, Poker is not actual poker). Ice storm is seriously difficult and a must for those who like arm-cramping-speed.

The graphics are very good even for today’s standard (the original game came out in the 90's); the resolutions are normal (800x600), High (1024x768) and Ultra (1920x1200). You can view the game in boxed or full screen - I prefer it in boxed since it makes the graphics crisper.

The backgrounds are beautiful and animated - they switch every level..

There are both in-game badges and steam achievements to earn with the game - which is really nice. :D

The game provides a lot of versatility and hours of fun - and to great music! I was surprised at how good the soundtrack was and I never get bored of it.

Also, about the Zen mode: It is not just soft music, it has a number of features like; instead of the music you can e.g. listen to the rain falling on leaves (there are 6 different ambient sounds to listen to besides the very nice music). You can also enable features like breath modulation - with or without visual indicator. Or why not enable mantras; e.g. positive thinking or self-confidence building (6 to choose from and there is also a subliminal" option for this - which I did not use since

reviewText:
This is how you create a match 3 puzzle game.

First off, the aesthetics are astounding. The graphics are incredible and the attention to detail is fantastic. Powered up gems flicker and give off light, and the stage transition looks and runs incredibly well even on my terrible Intel Integrated Graphics Card (which chokes on such intensive games such as They Bleed Pixels and Claydunn X2). The music sounds like something out of an RPG or strategy game. The game greets you every time you start it.

The basic game mode is straight up match 3 at its purest. No needless microtransactions, no extra powerups to earn, no items to bring down to the bottom, no need to break every single square of the game board. What really makes ther game shine, is the other unique game modes. Poker mode makes it so every match turns into a card. Lightning mode is similar to Bejeweled Blitz. Quest mode has you playing through various unique challenges. The board does not start out with matches. You can also never run out of moves in any mode except in Classic mode. None of these modes really feel too unfair, frustrating, or tedious.

The only issues I have with the game is that the Zen Mode is kind of tacked on (because all gamers need random motivational quotes to show up on screen while having on an effect that appearently causes nausea!). The other issue is that the entire game is mostly luck based. Though, that's really a problem with the genre itself.

This game is absolutely worth $10. I will never play Candy Crush again.

reviewText: If you're a Bejeweled beginner, here's how it works.\nDifferent-colored jewels fill an eight-by-eight board. To wipe them away, you create groups of at least three gems by swapping one gem with one located directly beside, above, or below it. This causes those gems to disappear and the ones above to drop down, allowing for new jewels to appear at the top. Matching four or more gems together creates a special gem that will explode and remove surrounding jewels when it is matched; the more jewels matched, the more powerful the explosion. Matching like-colored gems in a T- or L-shaped pattern creates a Box gem that will zap away all gems of a particular color.

Match-3 is about as basic as games get. Seriously, it's the first type of game most people are tasked with creating in game design school. So you've got to make an exceptional match-3 in order to deserve any praise for the task. The two most praised names in match-3 are Puzzle Quest, renowned for turning match-3 into a remarkably fun RPG, and Bejeweled.

The original Bejeweled was far more basic than Puzzle Quest, featuring a basic match-3 until you have no more matches gametype, and a time attack mode. These persisted into Bejeweled 2, which got a little creative on us, adding in a puzzle mode, some secret extra modes to spice things up, and special gems for matching 4 or 5 gems at once. Still not as unique as Puzzle Quest, but getting there.

So what sets Bejeweled 3 apart?

Two things, really. Game modes, which have evolved immensely from the previous two installments, and presentation. The game plays so smoothly. Matching feels great. Explosions feel great. The sound effects and vocal work both sound great. Everything is easy to figure out and menus are not a pain to navigate. B3 is even pleasant to look at.

reviewText:
Simply put: this is the game I wish all the other Bejeweled games could have been.

Gem SwappingOverall, the gem-swapping engine has been tweaked (or overhauled, I don't know), and it's obvious some serious thought was put into ironing out all the minor frustrations I've had with it. You can swap any gem at almost any time except when they're actively falling down the board. This means you can swap a gem into a falling column of other gems, make swaps while board animations are happening, and in a few other surprising places. It feels very polished (no pun intended).

Game ModesPretty much every mode from the first and second games are in there, plus a mode called Lightning that's very much like Bejeweled Blitz (though improved also, with no annoying Facebook tie-in), and a couple other non-timed modes that are seriously challenging and fun.

The new non-timed modes include Poker, in which you create hands" of cards by strategically matching gems. Butterflies has insect-gems that swap themselves upward on the board each time the player moves
date: and the game's over if the spider at the top catches any.\n\nDiamond Mine uses gem swaps to dig through dirt in search of treasure; clearing out enough dirt adds a bit of time to the countdown. Ice Storm features rising columns of ice behind the board that is shattered by swapping gems over them; if any columns freeze

I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

Bejeweled 3
Purchase Date: 3/6/2014

Match 3 puzzle games have been around a long time, and Bejeweled is one of the older series of these games.  If you ever played that awful Candy Crush Saga, then you can think of Bejeweled as it's much less obnoxious uncle.

Bejeweled 3 is a match 3 game first, and not a mobile game, so thankfully it doesn't have a lot of the annoying mechanics that you find in the typical mobile game.  It's not begging you to add friends or buy gems or enticing you to click on a picture of Kate Upton's boobs to download the latest version of Fire Age.  Bejewled 3 gives you a screen full of gems, and it wants you to match 3 of them, and that's as complicated as it gets.

In fairness, I should add that this version of Bejewled does come with 8 different game modes.  4 of these you get immediately, and as you progress in each game mode you will unlock an additional game mode.  So it does vary up the gameplay somewhat.  Some of the game modes are timed, while others are more strategic.  It also has a Zen mode where you can just mindlessly match gems as long as you want.

So the important question you need to ask yourself is, do you like matching gems?  Because if you like matching gems, then this game is for you.  If you don't like matching gems, then you should stop reading this review and get back to playing Fire Age.
